Identifying Characteristics: Conical shell that is not spiraled or coiled
Single filamentous gills on its underside
A singular muscular foot to apply suction combined with adhesive mucus to stay in place
Size: Adults only grow to be about 3 inches
Biology: Capable of locomotion—not permanently attached to a single spot in the water column
Height of the shell of a limpet is directly related to its habitat—living higher in or out of the water means a higher shell to allow a larger reserve of water to breathe
Diet: Herbivorous animals feeding on algae the scrape off the rock they live on
The slime trace they leave behind helps them in not visiting the same place twice
Limpets' slime helps in supporting algae growth—the limpet also sees to the restoration of its food sour
Habitat: Places rich in algae on most rocky shallow shores
Hard surfaces in the intertidal zone of bodies of water
